title: At the height of music sales in the late 1990s, how many artists made a living off music? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a lot more complicated than the supplied chart would imply. Technology is much more available than it once was. With an $80 Samson Go mic, a cello, an opensource suite of software (hell, Audacity alone cuts the cheese) and a few minutes spent knocking on my neighbor’s doors to request 30 minutes of silence, I can produce record-studio-quality tracks in my living room. If I want singing on it, I’d make a phone call to a bored friend. This might help explain why in spite of the decreasing revenue, there appear to actually be more artists, and better than there were during the peak days of the RIAA. This article does a pretty good job with it, I feel: Massive Growth In Independent Musicians & Singers Over The Past Decade | Techdirt with this graph being key:  The numbers most often cited are derived from the panic of an institution that is dying. The real story here is about how technology liberated artists from the institutions that were bludgeoning them to death… but that’s just from the perspective of a part-time musician. I’m sure the world looks differently to people who make their money by selling musicians, rather than selling music.
